Here's a pizza equation, to calculate the volume of a pizza. The volume is equal to the area times the height of the pizza. If we let "z" stand in for the radius, and "a" stand in for the height of the pizza, we get the following equation.

V = Pi*z*z*a

It could also be that the margins on smaller pizzas are already so big that pizza venders don't need to increase prices proportionate to increases in pizza areas in order to still be very profitable.

In order words, it may just be that the smaller pizzas are incredibly overpriced.
If Z=radius,  then Pi * z * z = a.

This means that a smaller pizza is more expensive per square inch. This makes economic sense since the pizza place needs to invest more human work hours per pizza inch on the smaller pizzas. The time it takes for a pizza employee to handle a small pizza is almost equal to the time it takes to handle a large one, so a lot more work is invested in each inch of the smaller pizza. This is a classic example of economics of scale. The bigger you make it, the cheaper it becomes per item (or square inch).

Ever since that 'Planet Money' episode I've been pulling for the bigger pizza.

You also need to consider that the crust is the most rapidly growing portion of the pizza. It is still a better price per inch to get larger pizza but it diminishes the returns of increasing pizza sizes and should be considered when mathematically deciding what to eat. Some people don't eat the crust at all and 100% of it will be going to waste, this is important when considering a party pizza because a square pizza will have a larger perimeter (and thus more crust) than a traditionally round pizza.

"Hey USA, you know how we have an obesity problem? Well on an unrelated note; always order the largest pizza! Also supersize every order if possible".
The price per pound of pizza doesn't increase linearly because the materials costs aren't the only costs in making a pizza. It's a lot more work making 8 small pizzas than one really large pizza. It also takes a lot more ovens (or oven time) to cook those 8 small pizzas. And companies like selling a lot of stuff so if you decide to bulk buy your pizza, i.e. give them a lot more money than you would if you bought a single small item, they can afford to give you a discount.

The reason why 8 smaller pizzas cost more than 1 20 inch pizza is not because they don't understand how pricing works. Many things involved in making pizza i.e. Labor costs and room in a pizza oven only increase when you add more pizzas not the size.
Explanation it will take the same amount of time to measure out 10 oz of cheese as it does 20.
Explanation: most pizza ovens have a set width and roll on their length which limits the combined diameter of pizzas it can fit. Regardless of the area.

Economics might help explain the cost discrepancy. According to the Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility, satisfaction decreases the more you consume. So the 1st slice of pizza will be delicious, but the 7th slice of pizza is comparatively meh.
The 20" pizza contains 6.25x more pizza than the 8" pizza. But it does not provide 6.25x more satisfaction than the 8" pizza. So you wouldn't be willing to pay so much more for the 20" than the 8".

Pizza companies have assumed that the 20" pizza provides about 2.4x as much satisfaction as an 8" pizza. So while an 8" costs about $8.59, the 20" costs $20.77. You wouldn't be willing to pay $51.56 for a 20" pizza, and companies aren't willing to sell at $3.49 for an 8" pizza.
This price scheme seems wrong by intuition, but in fact is perfect according to economics. Obviously, ASAPScience doesn't get into the economics too much, so I'll do it for them.

The price difference probably comes from economies of scale. It's counter intuitive, but it costs less to make a larger pizza because the means of preparation (boxes, plates, ovens, etc.) are roughly the same regardless of pizza size. Since the ingredients are also fairly cheap, you can actually charge less per square inch of pizza because there are more square inches there to distribute the costs.

The actual ingredients make up only a small percentage of the cost of a pizza. You also have to pay the staff's wages, the restaurant's bills, etc. Most of those costs are fixed per pizza (e.g. prep time of an 8" and 16" pizza are nearly identical), regardless of size, so of course cost scales sublinearly with size. This is true for basically anything you buy, which is why buying in bulk makes a sense if you have room to store it and it won't go bad.

People choose the size of the pizza's not by the area but by the portion, a 12" pizza is cut in 6 slices while a 14" pizza is cut in 8 slices and the difference in price is $12 vs $15 for the large pie. (3.14X36)/6=18.84sqin @ $2 ea VS (3.14X49)/8=19.23sqin @ $1.87 ea. The math prove it that the largest pizza has the largest portion giving the best value per portion. Another fact that is unnoticed is that perhaps both sizes of pizza has the same amount of dough, the pizza guy just has to extent and make a little wider pie for the larger pizza, just the amount of toppings differ, tomato sauce and mozzarella cheese and pepperoni and so on, which is more for the larger pie.

This is not just the case with pizza, but nearly anything you can purchase.
